title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
West Coast Neuroecon 2025 is organized by:



University of California, Los Angeles
Dr. Ian Krajbich is a leading researcher in neuroeconomics and decision neuroscience. His work focuses on understanding the computational and neural mechanisms underlying value-based decision-making, using a combination of behavioral experiments, computational modeling, and neuroimaging techniques.
Research Interests: - Value-based decision making - Computational modeling of choice - Visual attention and choice - Food and consumer decisions
Faculty Profile (Link to be updated)



University of California, Los Angeles
Dr. Kianté Fernandez conducts research at the intersection of neuroscience, economics, and decision-making. Their work contributes to our understanding of how neural systems support economic choices and decision processes.
Research Interests: - Neuroeconomics - Decision neuroscience - Cognitive neuroscience
Faculty Profile (Link to be updated)

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Organizing Committee
Additional organizing committee members will be announced soon.

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Sponsors & Support
We welcome sponsorship support for West Coast Neuroecon 2025. Your sponsorship helps make this important academic gathering possible and supports the neuroeconomics research community.

Become a Sponsor
We are currently seeking sponsors for the 2025 symposium. Sponsorship opportunities are available at various levels.
To discuss sponsorship options, please contact us at wcneuroecon@gmail.com.


Why Sponsor?
Supporting West Coast Neuroecon provides:

Visibility: Exposure to leading researchers and academics in neuroeconomics
Community Support: Direct contribution to advancing scientific knowledge
Networking: Opportunities to connect with the research community
Recognition: Acknowledgment at the symposium and on our website
Impact: Help support student travel grants and make the symposium accessible



Sponsorship Levels
We offer several sponsorship tiers to fit different budgets and goals:
Platinum Sponsor - Benefits include: - Prominent logo placement on website and symposium materials - Acknowledgment in opening and closing remarks - Opportunity for brief remarks at symposium - Recognition in program materials - Social media recognition - 2 complimentary registrations
Gold Sponsor - Benefits include: - Logo placement on website and symposium materials - Acknowledgment in opening remarks - Recognition in program materials - Social media recognition - 1 complimentary registration
Silver Sponsor - Benefits include: - Logo placement on website - Recognition in program materials - Social media recognition
Bronze Sponsor - Benefits include: - Name listing on website - Recognition in program materials
In-Kind Sponsorship - We also welcome in-kind donations such as: - Coffee and catering services - Printing services - Technology and AV support - Venue support

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Acknowledgments
We gratefully acknowledge the support of our sponsors and partners:

Major Support

The Luskin Lecture for Thought Leadership
We are proud to acknowledge the generous support of The Luskin Lecture for Thought Leadership at UCLA College.
The Luskin Lecture for Thought Leadership was established in 2011 as part of a transformative gift from Meyer and Renee Luskin. The lecture series has featured distinguished speakers including President Bill Clinton, Kofi Annan, Hillary Rodham Clinton, and other world leaders, giving UCLA College an opportunity to share knowledge and expand the dialogue among scholars, leaders in government and business, and the greater Los Angeles community.
Learn more about the Luskin Lecture



Institutional Supporters





UCLA


University of California, Los Angeles - Anderson School of Management - Department of Economics - Department of Psychology - UCLA College





Society for Neuroeconomics


Society for Neuroeconomics
The Society for Neuroeconomics is an interdisciplinary academic society promoting research on the neural and psychological mechanisms underlying economic decision-making.


Additional sponsors will be listed here as they are confirmed.

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Academic Partnerships
We welcome partnerships with academic societies, departments, and research centers. If your organization is interested in partnering with West Coast Neuroecon, please get in touch.

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Student Travel Support
A portion of sponsorship funds goes toward supporting student travel grants, helping ensure that graduate students can participate in the symposium regardless of their financial circumstances.

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Volunteer Opportunities
We welcome volunteers to help with symposium organization and logistics. If you are interested in volunteering, please contact us at wcneuroecon@gmail.com.

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Contact the Organizers
For questions, suggestions, or inquiries about the symposium, sponsorship, or volunteering:
Email: wcneuroecon@gmail.com

title: Organizers & Sponsors
text:
Previous Organizers & History
The West Coast Neuroeconomics symposium has been successfully organized by various institutions over the years. We thank all previous organizers for their contributions to building this important community event.
Past Host Institutions: - UC San Diego (Rady School of Management) - And other West Coast institutions
We are excited to continue this tradition at UCLA’s Meyer & Renee Luskin Conference Center in 2025.

title: Quick Start Guide
text:
This guide will help you quickly get started with updating and maintaining the West Coast Neuroecon website.




quarto preview
This opens a live preview in your browser that automatically updates when you save changes to any .qmd file.



Try editing index.qmd to update the conference date or location. Save the file and watch the preview update automatically!







Open index.qmd and replace “TBD 2025” with actual dates
Update program.qmd with the schedule
Update registration.qmd with registration deadlines





Open speakers.qmd
Replace the placeholder content with speaker information:

## Keynote Speaker

### Dr. Jane Smith
**University of Example**

Dr. Smith is a leading researcher in neuroeconomics...

[Website](https://example.com) | [Google Scholar](#)

Optional: Add speaker photos to images/speakers/ directory





Open program.qmd
Update the schedule table with actual times and sessions
Add session descriptions and topics





Add logo images to images/sponsors/ directory
Open sponsors.qmd
Add sponsor information:

### Platinum Sponsors

![Sponsor Name](images/sponsors/logo.png)

**Sponsor Name** - Brief description







Make sure all changes are committed:

git add .
git commit -m "Update conference website"
git push

Go to your GitHub repository Settings > Pages
Set source to “Deploy from a branch”
Select main branch and /docs folder
Save




Every time you make changes:
quarto render              # Build the site
git add .                  # Stage changes
git commit -m "Your message"  # Commit changes
git push                   # Push to GitHub
GitHub will automatically deploy your changes in a few minutes.




WCNE/
├── _quarto.yml           # Main configuration
├── *.qmd                 # Content pages
├── styles/               # CSS and SCSS files
│   ├── custom.scss       # Theme customization
│   └── styles.css        # Additional styles
├── images/               # Images and logos
│   ├── speakers/         # Speaker photos
│   └── sponsors/         # Sponsor logos
└── docs/                 # Generated website (don't edit directly)




Always preview before deploying: Use quarto preview to check your changes
Keep it simple: Quarto uses Markdown - it’s easy to learn!
Use headers: Structure your content with #, ##, ### for headings
Add images: Use ![Alt text](path/to/image.png) to add images
Create links: Use [Link text](url) for links




# Large Heading
## Medium Heading
### Small Heading

**Bold text**
*Italic text*

- Bullet point
- Another point

1. Numbered list
2. Second item

[Link](https://example.com)
![Image](path/to/image.png)



Use these special boxes in your content:
::: {.info-box}
This is an information box
:::

::: {.important-box}
This is an important notice box
:::




Quarto Documentation
Markdown Guide
Email: wcneuroecon@gmail.com




Site won’t build? - Check for syntax errors in .qmd files - Make sure YAML front matter is correct (between ---)
Changes not showing on GitHub Pages? - Wait a few minutes for deployment - Check that you ran quarto render before pushing - Verify Settings > Pages is configured correctly
Preview not working? - Make sure you’re in the project directory - Check that Quarto is installed: quarto --version

title: Attend
text:
West Coast Neuroecon 2025 May 1-2, 2025 Meyer & Renee Luskin Conference Center, UCLA
Registration for West Coast Neuroecon 2025 will open soon. This page will be updated with registration details, fees, and the registration link once available.

Registration Opening Soon
We are currently finalizing registration details for this two-day symposium. The registration system will open in the coming weeks.
To receive notification when registration opens, please email us at wcneuroecon@gmail.com with “Registration Notification” in the subject line.



The symposium welcomes decision scientists from across disciplines:

Faculty and Researchers: Academic researchers working in neuroeconomics, decision neuroscience, and related fields
Graduate Students: PhD students conducting research in relevant areas
Postdoctoral Researchers: Postdocs interested in neuroeconomics and decision science
West Coast Researchers: Participants from institutions across the West Coast
Los Angeles Area Researchers: Colleagues from Caltech, USC, UCLA, and other LA institutions
Industry Professionals: Practitioners in decision science and behavioral economics




Registration fees will be announced when registration opens. We expect to offer:

title: Attend
text:
Venue & Location

Meyer & Renee Luskin Conference Center
University of California, Los Angeles 425 Westwood Plaza Los Angeles, CA 90095
Luskin Conference Center Website


About the Venue
The Meyer & Renee Luskin Conference Center is a world-class conference facility located in the heart of UCLA’s campus. This LEED Platinum-certified building exemplifies sustainability while providing state-of-the-art facilities for academic gatherings.
Venue Highlights:

25,000 square feet of multi-purpose meeting and event space
LEED Platinum certified for sustainable design
254 guest rooms with luxurious amenities
On-site dining at Plateia restaurant (Mediterranean-inspired, California-fresh)
State-of-the-art facilities for conferences and symposia
Located on UCLA campus in the Westwood neighborhood of Los Angeles

Facilities & Amenities:

Complimentary high-speed Wi-Fi connected to UCLA Campus Backbone Network
Well-equipped fitness center
Business center
Professional on-site catering services
24-hour front desk
Convenient access to UCLA facilities and resources

title: Attend
text:
Getting to UCLA

By Air
Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) - Approximately 13 miles from UCLA campus - Major international airport with connections worldwide - Ground transportation options include: - Ride-share services (Uber, Lyft) - Taxi services - Rental cars - Public transportation via Metro
Alternative Airports: - Burbank Bob Hope Airport (BUR) - About 20 miles - Long Beach Airport (LGB) - About 30 miles - John Wayne Airport (SNA) - About 45 miles


By Car
UCLA is located in Westwood, easily accessible via: - I-405 Freeway (exit Wilshire Blvd or Sunset Blvd) - Sunset Boulevard - Wilshire Boulevard
Parking: Campus parking information and visitor permits will be provided to registered attendees.


Public Transportation
Metro: - Metro Bus routes serve UCLA campus - Westwood/UCLA Station (coming soon on Metro D Line Extension)
Big Blue Bus: - Multiple Santa Monica Big Blue Bus routes serve UCLA

title: Attend
text:
Accommodations

On-Site Hotel
The Luskin Conference Center features 254 beautifully appointed guest rooms, making it convenient to stay right at the venue. Rooms include:

Premium and earth-friendly amenities
Pima cotton linens
Modern technology and connectivity
Warm, comfortable ambiance
Direct access to conference facilities

Booking Information: Details on room rates and how to reserve accommodation at the Luskin Conference Center will be posted soon.
Visit Luskin Conference Center


Additional Hotels Near Campus
For additional accommodation options, consider these nearby areas: - Westwood Village (walking distance) - Brentwood - Santa Monica - West Los Angeles
Room block information and discounted rates will be announced soon.

title: Attend
text:
Local Information

Dining Options
At the Venue: - Plateia Restaurant: Mediterranean-inspired, California-fresh cuisine and lounge located in the Luskin Conference Center - In-room dining service available
Nearby: - Westwood Village: Wide variety of restaurants within walking distance - On-Campus Dining: Multiple UCLA cafes and dining halls - Nearby Neighborhoods: Santa Monica, Brentwood, and West LA offer extensive dining choices


Things to Do in Los Angeles
While attending the symposium, you may want to explore:


Cultural Attractions - Getty Center - LACMA (Los Angeles County Museum of Art) - Hammer Museum (on UCLA campus) - California Science Center - Griffith Observatory


Outdoor Activities - Santa Monica Pier and Beach - Griffith Park hiking trails - Venice Beach - Malibu beaches - Runyon Canyon




Weather
Early May in Los Angeles: - Average temperature: 60-70°F (16-21°C) - Generally sunny and mild, perfect for outdoor activities - Light jacket recommended for air-conditioned spaces and evenings


Campus Map & Directions
The Luskin Conference Center is located at 425 Westwood Plaza in the heart of UCLA’s campus.
UCLA Campus Map | Luskin Conference Center Map
Detailed directions and parking information will be provided to registered attendees.


Accessibility
The Luskin Conference Center and UCLA are committed to accessibility. The facility is fully ADA-compliant and accessible to individuals with disabilities. If you have specific accessibility needs, please contact us at wcneuroecon@gmail.com and we will ensure appropriate accommodations.

title: West Coast Neuroecon 2025
text:
Date: May 1-2, 2025 Location: Luskin Conference Center, UCLA Keynote: Prof. Christian Ruff, PhD (University of Zurich)
Registration Information Contact Us

title: West Coast Neuroecon 2025
text:
Welcome
The West Coast Neuroeconomics Mini-Symposium brings together decision scientists from across the West Coast and beyond. This annual event provides a platform for sharing cutting-edge research, fostering collaborations, and advancing our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying economic decision-making.
We expect an engaging and collaborative atmosphere with plenty of opportunities for discussion and connection. We hope to attract participants from throughout Los Angeles including Caltech, USC, and UCLA, as well as researchers from across the West Coast.

Why Attend?

Distinguished Keynote: Hear from Prof. Christian Ruff on cutting-edge neuroeconomics research
Collaborative Environment: Engage in meaningful discussions with colleagues
West Coast Community: Connect with decision scientists from leading institutions
Interactive Sessions: Participate in talks, posters, and networking opportunities

title: West Coast Neuroecon 2025
text:
About the Symposium
The West Coast Neuroeconomics Mini-Symposium is an annual gathering dedicated to advancing the field of neuroeconomics through the presentation and discussion of cutting-edge research. The symposium brings together decision scientists from across the West Coast and beyond, including leading researchers, graduate students, and practitioners interested in understanding the neural, psychological, and computational mechanisms underlying economic decision-making.

Mission
Our mission is to:

Foster Collaboration: Create opportunities for researchers across institutions to connect and collaborate
Share Knowledge: Provide a platform for presenting and discussing the latest findings in neuroeconomics
Train Future Researchers: Support graduate students and early-career researchers in developing their work
Bridge Disciplines: Promote interdisciplinary dialogue between neuroscience, economics, psychology, and related fields



What is Neuroeconomics?
Neuroeconomics is an interdisciplinary field that combines methods from neuroscience, economics, and psychology to study how the brain makes decisions. The field examines:

How neural systems represent value and process rewards
The computational mechanisms underlying choice behavior
How social context influences decision-making
The role of emotions and cognitive processes in economic choices
Applications to understanding real-world decision-making in markets, policy, and everyday life



Academic Focus Areas
Topics covered at the symposium include:


Core Topics - Value-based decision making - Reward processing and learning - Risk and uncertainty - Temporal discounting - Social decision making - Strategic thinking and game theory


Methods and Applications - fMRI and neuroimaging techniques - Computational modeling - Behavioral experiments - Eye-tracking and psychophysiology - Applications to policy and health - Consumer neuroscience

title: West Coast Neuroecon 2025
text:
Keynote Speaker

Prof. Christian Ruff, PhD
Professor of Neuroeconomics and Decision Neuroscience University of Zurich, Department of Economics Director, Laboratory for Social and Neural Systems Research
Prof. Ruff is a leading figure in neuroeconomics whose research focuses on human motivation, decision-making, and learning. His work develops models to explain and predict choices and social behavior across diverse contexts, using a multi-methods approach that combines behavioral experiments and computational modeling with neuroimaging and brain stimulation.
After studying psychology, cognitive science, and neurobiology in Freiburg (Germany) and Vancouver (Canada), Prof. Ruff obtained his PhD in cognitive neuroscience at University College London in 2007. He founded the Laboratory for Social and Neural Systems Research (SNS Lab) in 2007 and has been at the University of Zurich since 2010.
Research Interests: - Neural mechanisms of decision-making and social behavior - Computational modeling of choice and learning - Value-based decision processes - Brain stimulation and neuroimaging methods
Faculty Profile | Google Scholar


Additional Speakers
We are currently confirming additional invited speakers for West Coast Neuroecon 2025. Speaker announcements will be made in the coming weeks. Stay tuned for updates!

title: West Coast Neuroecon 2025
text:
Symposium Program
Dates: May 1-2, 2025 Location: Meyer & Renee Luskin Conference Center, UCLA
The detailed program for West Coast Neuroecon 2025 will be announced soon. Check back for updates on session times, speakers, and topics.

Tentative Schedule
The symposium will span two days, May 1-2, 2025:

Day 1 - Thursday, May 1 (Tentative)



Time
Session




8:30 AM - 9:00 AM
Registration & Coffee


9:00 AM - 9:15 AM
Welcome & Opening Remarks


9:15 AM - 10:30 AM
Keynote: Prof. Christian Ruff


10:30 AM - 11:00 AM
Coffee Break


11:00 AM - 12:30 PM
Invited Talks Session 1


12:30 PM - 2:00 PM
Lunch


2:00 PM - 3:30 PM
Contributed Talks Session 1


3:30 PM - 4:00 PM
Afternoon Coffee


4:00 PM - 5:30 PM
Poster Session 1


6:00 PM onwards
Reception (Optional)





Day 2 - Friday, May 2 (Tentative)



Time
Session




8:30 AM - 9:00 AM
Coffee


9:00 AM - 10:30 AM
Invited Talks Session 2


10:30 AM - 11:00 AM
Coffee Break


11:00 AM - 12:30 PM
Contributed Talks Session 2


12:30 PM - 2:00 PM
Lunch


2:00 PM - 3:30 PM
Poster Session 2 / Panel Discussion


3:30 PM - 4:00 PM
Afternoon Coffee


4:00 PM - 5:00 PM
Discussion & Future Directions


5:00 PM - 5:30 PM
Closing Remarks



Note: This is a tentative schedule and may be adjusted based on the final program and number of submissions.



Session Topics
While the specific sessions are still being finalized, we expect to cover topics including:
Core Research Areas: - Value-Based Decision Making: Neural mechanisms underlying how we assign value to different options - Social Neuroeconomics: Decision-making in social contexts, cooperation, and strategic interactions - Computational Approaches: Modeling frameworks for understanding choice behavior - Learning and Memory: How experience shapes future decisions - Risk and Uncertainty: Neural and behavioral responses to probabilistic outcomes
Methodological Advances: - Novel neuroimaging techniques and analysis methods - Combining multiple modalities (fMRI, EEG, eye-tracking, etc.) - Large-scale data analysis and meta-analyses - Translational applications and real-world validation


Call for Abstracts

Submit Your Research
We welcome abstract submissions for contributed talks and poster presentations. Details on abstract submission will be available soon.
Submission Guidelines (Coming Soon): - Abstract deadline: TBD - Notification of acceptance: TBD - Format: 250-word abstract - Topics: All areas of neuroeconomics



Symposium Format
The symposium typically features:

Invited Talks: Presentations from leading researchers in the field
Contributed Talks: Selected presentations from submitted abstracts
Poster Sessions: Opportunities for informal discussion and networking
Panel Discussions: Conversations on important topics and future directions
Networking Events: Social gatherings to facilitate connections and collaborations

title: West Coast Neuroecon 2025
text:
History
The West Coast Neuroeconomics symposium has been bringing together the decision science community for several years. Previous symposiums have been hosted at various institutions across the West Coast, including UC San Diego’s Rady School of Management, featuring presentations from leading researchers and fostering important collaborations that have advanced the field.
This year, we are excited to host the symposium at UCLA’s prestigious Meyer & Renee Luskin Conference Center, continuing our tradition of excellence and expanding our reach within the research community.
